Dave,

Thanks for the help.  I had some chemkin input files around and
created the xml input using your utility and all works fine.  

Have Cantera sucked into my code to calculate relatively simple
mixture properties as a first step.  

Cantera looks like a nice package - thanks for sharing the code.  I
occasionally have to brush the dust off my fortran skills to use
chemkin.  Looks like those days may be over.

-Pete

--- In cantera@yahoogroups.com, David Goodwin <dgoodwin@c...> wrote:
> Pete,
> 
> There are a couple of problems.  First of all, file nasa.cti only  
> contains species data, so these definitions need to be imported into
an  
> "ideal_gas" entry in another .cti file.  You can write a simple one  
> like this:
> 
> ideal_gas(name = "gas",
>           elements = "O H C N Ar Al E",
>           species = "nasa:all ",
>            options = ['skip_undeclared_elements'],
>            initial_state = state(temperature = 300.0, pressure = OneAtm)
>            )
> 
> Set the element list to whatever elements you are interested in - the  
> rest of the species will be skipped. But note that this will pick up  
> the liquid and solid species in nasa.cti too.  To get rid of these,  
> edit nasa.cti first.
> 
> But there are 2 more minor problems.  File nasa.cti has a formatting  
> error - there is a comma missing on the line before "note" in each  
> entry. So open it in a text editor and globally replace "note" by  
> either ", note" or by "# note".
> 
> The next problem is that the species import process expects to find an  
> xml file, not a cti file (this will be fixed someday).  So run program  
> 'cti2ctml' on nasa.cti to generate nasa.xml.  Or just get nasa.xml  
> here:
> 
> http://rayleigh.cds.caltech.edu/~goodwin/nasa.xml
> 
> In the modified 'demo.cpp' program, use the .cti file with the  
> ideal_gas entry listed above, and it should work.
> 
> Dave
>
